newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil coffee temps seen well above critical level.
newsitem.headline: Brazil coffee temps seen well above critical level.

text.p: Early morning temperatures in key Brazilian coffee regions are not expected to fall below eight degrees Celsius in the coming days, said local independent meteorologists Somar.

A polar air mass which caused widespread frosts early this morning in southern states is expected to keep temperatures cool in north Parana, Sao Paulo and south Minas Gerais but there is no risk of any frosts, said forecaster Marcio Custodio.
An approaching low pressure system is likely to lead to increasing cloud cover, adding further protection for the coffee regions, he added.
A second air mass is expected to reach the country's southern states on May 25 but this is coming from the sea and poses no threat for coffee, Custodio said.
Temperatures will start to pick up again from the early morning of May 29, he added.
There is no other polar air mass in sight in the long-term forecast to June 2, Custodio said.
Traditionally Brazil's coffee regions only come under real threat of frost from June to mid-August.
